docs.lead_paragraph: It is difficult to doubt Philip M. Condit when he says his most important management rule at Boeing is to be a good listener. After all, he seems to have been sent over from central casting for the role of chief listener. He is as approachable as a good high school science teacher -- and then there are his ears, which are of a rather impressive size. And Mr. Condit knows how to poke fun at himself; when he led the development of the 777 jet, he established the Golden Ears award for employees whose listening skills led to innovations.

headline.main: Boeing Chief Wants McDonnell but Not Old Rivalries
headline.kicker: Perfect Match, but Will It Mesh?

docs.abstract: Profile of Philip M Condit, Boeing Co's chief executive, and challenge he faces over next few years of getting combined 200,000 employees of Boeing and McDonnell Douglas Corp united once planned merger of two companies is completed; Condit, in discussing challenges, says his most important management rule at Boeing is being good listener; his photo; charts, graphs on Boeing personnel airplane production and business cycles (L)
docs.snippet: It is difficult to doubt Philip M. Condit when he says his most important management rule at Boeing is to be a good listener.    After all, he seems to have been sent over from central casting for the role of chief listener. He is as approachable as...

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the objections of senior members of his own party, President Clinton is drafting a budget that would set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending as a way to help balance the Federal budget by 2002. While the effort at fiscal discipline may please Republicans, many Democrats view the limits as undermining the open-ended nature of the Federal-state health program for the poor. Furthermore, they say they see no need for such limits because the program's growth fell last year to its lowest level in two decades.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, over objections of senior members of own party, is drafting budget that would set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending as way to help balance Federal budget by 2002; many Democrats view limits as undermining open-ended nature of Federal-state health programs for poor; say there is no need for such limits because program's overall growth fell in '96 to lowest levels in two decades; Administration will ask Congress to squeeze at least $11 billion, and perhaps twice amount, from Medicaid over next five years, by imposing annual limits on spending and cutting payments to hospitals with large number of indigent patients; assumes that, with no change in current law, Medicaid will grow roughly 7.5 percent per year for next five years, so that Federal Medicaid spending in period will be $55 billion less than projected 11 months ago; Medicaid spending rose average of 15 percent annually between 1985 and 1995, but growth slowed, averaging 7.9 percent per year from 1992 to 1996; during past year outlays increased just 3.3 percent, to $92 billion, or $3 billion less than Clinton predicted in budget sent to Congress in February '96 (M)
docs.snippet: Over the objections of senior members of his own party, President Clinton is drafting a budget that would set firm limits on Federal Medicaid spending as a way to help balance the Federal budget by 2002.    While the effort at fiscal discipline may...

docs.lead_paragraph: During the Depression, when so many people felt vulnerable to poverty, America developed a ''one for all, all for one'' economic system. New government safety nets like Social Security and welfare came into existence, and corporations took on new responsibilties for the well-being of their workers. But now this communal system is giving way to a do-it-yourself approach that increasingly requires Americans to make their own way. The proposals last week to revamp Social Security, so that workers finance their own retirements rather than those of their elders, are the latest manifestation of this shift in the American ethic toward greater self-reliance, even for those who don't make ends meet.

headline.main: The Shift Toward Self-Reliance in the Welfare System

docs.abstract: Analysis: communal aspects of Social Security system is giving way to do-it-yourself approach that increasingly requires Americans to make their own way; recent proposals to revamp system, so that workers finance their own retirements rather than those of elders, are latest manifestation of shift in American ethic toward greater self-reliance, even for those who cannot make ends meet (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Republicans swept into office on Capitol Hill two years ago, there was much talk about a vast transfer of power and money from Washington to the states. Entire Federal programs in such areas as welfare, environmental protection and highway maintenance would be radically transformed into block grants, they said, with state leaders exercising wisdom on how best to spend the money. In welfare, that process has begun to happen, after Congress passed a sweeping bill last summer that ended the Federal Government's six-decade-old guarantee of cash assistance to the poor. But even with welfare grants set to flow to the states, Federal regulators are still intimately involved in approving scores of details in the states' welfare plans.

headline.main: Legislators Meet, Surprised at Limit On Shift of Power

docs.abstract: Legislators, gathering at state capitols around nation for new sessions, express surprise at how limited transfer of power from Federal Government to states has been so far compared with vast transfer envisioned when Republicans took control of Congress two years ago; 'devolution' movement has been slow; many state legislators are skeptical that Congress will ever yield significant authority over many spending programs; graph; table (M)
docs.snippet: When Republicans swept into office on Capitol Hill two years ago, there was much talk about a vast transfer of power and money from Washington to the states. Entire Federal programs in such areas as welfare, environmental protection and highway...

docs.lead_paragraph: EIGHT and one-half million dollars. That is the projected savings that hospitals in the Westchester area expect to achieve this year by joining forces and becoming members of the Health Star Network in Armonk. Health Star, organized to help community hospitals deal with the sharp changes in the industry, became the first major health care network in the area last September as the result of the alliance of Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco and White Plains Hospital Medical Center. In November, Putnam Hospital Center in Carmel, Putnam County's largest health care organization and Putnam County's largest employer, became a member. And Jan. 3, Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville announced its plans to join, too.

headline.main: Hospitals Unite for Savings and Care

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Cecilia Chadderton began having trouble breathing during her seventh month of pregnancy she was worried. A visit to North Shore Hospital in Manhasset intensified her fears when doctors found a five-inch tumor growing on her sternum. The pressure from the baby and the tumor had collapsed her lungs. Doctors delivered her baby girl two months early, and Mrs. Chadderton went into chemotherapy for four months. Nine months after the birth of her daughter on July 4, 1989, Mrs. Chadderton, who is from West Hempstead, went back to North Shore Hospital for a bone marrow transplant, remaining there for three months. Besides being confident of good medical treatment, the 15- to 30-minute trip to the hospital was a convenience, she said, as she recalled the death of her sister from cancer five years earlier.
docs.abstract: More hospitals on Long Island, NY, are providing cancer care; as advanced technology in radiation and chemotherapy becomes more available, it is offered on outpatient basis by hospitals and medical centers like Stony Brook University Hospital, St John's Episcopal in Smithtown, Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, Southampton Hospital and Don Monti Cancer Centers, which operate at seven community hospitals affiliated with North Shore Health System; State Health Department says Long Island averaged more than 12,000 cancer cases a year between 1988 and 1992, with 5,458.2 in Suffolk and 6,749.4 in Nassau; twenty percent of Island residents with cancer are treated at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Presidential campaign over, the economy stable and considerable progress already recorded in reducing the Federal deficit, the Clinton Administration and the Republican leaders in Congress agree that the coming months offer the best, and maybe last, opportunity for reaching agreement on balancing the budget. But after years of battles over how to do it, Democrats and Republicans still have deep differences on a variety of politically explosive issues that they will have to address to reach their goal of eliminating the deficit by 2002.

headline.main: Sharp Differences and Compromise Are Likely on Budget

docs.abstract: Democrats and Republicans, after years of battles over how to balance budget, still have deep differences on variety of politically explosive issues they will have to address to reach goal of eliminating deficit by 2002; Pres Clinton prepares five-year budget proposal that will call for more spending on social programs than plan Republicans will offer in Mar; Republicans will also continue to call for deeper tax cuts than Clinton wants (M)
docs.snippet: With the Presidential campaign over, the economy stable and considerable progress already recorded in reducing the Federal deficit, the Clinton Administration and the Republican leaders in Congress agree that the coming months offer the best, and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago Congress overhauled the tax code, wiping out scores of loopholes and creating a system that was simpler and fairer and put nearly everyone in a lower tax bracket. Unfortunately, that worthy reform has been partly unraveled over the years by Congress, which has created new breaks for favored constituents, and by crafty lawyers. Sadly, the White House and Congress now appear intent on doing still more harm when they take up the budget early next month. The Times documented, in a series of articles last year, how upper-income families escape taxation of much of their capital gains income, their estates and even a portion of their salaries that they arrange to postpone. Most of these tax breaks siphon money from the Treasury, forcing Congress either to cut spending or tax other constituents higher. Congress displays little stomach for whittling away at these loopholes -- and little hesitation in creating new ones.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges Clinton Administration and Congress to reconsider plans for additional tax breaks, including child tax credit, reduction in capital gains tax, college-tuition credit; says everyone's taxes could be reduced if Congress were to close tax loopholes created since 1986, limiting business deductions for fringe benefits like health and life insurance; says corporate profits should be taxed only on corporate level, not a second time as shareholder dividends

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a scheme afoot to privatize Social Security. My son the poor but honest carpenter asked what that would mean. ''Son,'' I told him, ''it means in your old age you will be taken care of by the bottom-line guys.''
docs.abstract: Russell Baker column on calls for privatizing Social Security, investing funds in the stock market (M)
docs.snippet: There is a scheme afoot to privatize Social Security. My son the poor but honest carpenter asked what that would mean.     ''Son,'' I told him, ''it means in your old age you will be taken care of by the bottom-line guys.''

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that has alarmed employers across the nation, the Labor Department has enlisted state officials in an experimental program to protect consumers who are denied health benefits by self-insured companies. The vast majority of large and midsize employers are self-insured and therefore are exempt from state insurance regulation under a longstanding Federal pension and welfare law. Under a two-year agreement signed yesterday by the Oklahoma Insurance Commissioner, John P. Crawford, state officials will help officials of the Federal Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration, which regulates the self-insurance companies, to lean on employers to resolve health care complaints.
docs.abstract: Labor Department, in move that has alarms employers across the nation, enlists state officials in an experimental program to protect consumers who are denied health benefits by self-insured companies; under two-year agreement signed by Oklahoma Insurance Commissioner, John P Crawford, state officials will help officials of Federal Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration, which regulates self-insurance companies, to pressure employers to resolve health care complaints; program answers common complaint that Federal officials are spread to thin to regulate companies that finance their own health insurance plans; James A Klein, president of Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, Washington trade group, comments (M)
